title: Evaluate wrapper scripts requiring permission flags for gh and git commit
description:
## Problem

Claude has bypassed pre-commit hooks and created PRs without permission, violating project rules. The CLAUDE.md rules help but don't technically enforce compliance.

## Proposed Solution

Create wrapper scripts that intercept sensitive commands and require explicit permission flags:

### git wrapper
- Intercept `git commit` commands
- Require `--i-have-permission` flag to allow `--no-verify`
- Block `-n` / `--no-verify` without the permission flag
- Pass through all other git commands unchanged

### gh wrapper  
- Intercept `gh pr create` and `gh pr merge` commands
- Require `--i-have-permission` flag
- Block these commands without the flag
- Pass through all other gh commands unchanged

## Evaluation Criteria

- Can this be done via Nix flake shell hooks?
- Should it be shell aliases or actual wrapper binaries?
- How to make error messages clear about why the command was blocked?
- Does this integrate well with the existing pre-commit setup?

## Alternatives

- Claude Code hooks that intercept commands (if supported)
- Git hooks that check for permission markers
- Just rely on CLAUDE.md rules (current state)

title: Phase 2: Vendor go-unifi Codegen
description:
**BEFORE STARTING:** Read the full implementation plan at:
/Users/coneill/.claude/plans/enchanted-imagining-breeze.md

## Steps
1. Create `.go-unifi-version` file with pinned version
2. Create `task sync-gounifi` that:
   - Clones go-unifi at pinned version to `.tmp/go-unifi/`
   - Copies `codegen/{resources,customize,validation}.go` to `internal/gounifi/`
   - Patches `package main` ‚Üí `package gounifi`
   - Adds attribution headers to each file
3. Create `internal/gounifi/README.md` with prominent attribution
4. Add Renovate custom manager for `.go-unifi-version`
5. Write integration test that imports gounifi and parses a sample JSON spec

## Why Vendor?
go-unifi's codegen is `package main` and cannot be imported directly.
We copy these files and change the package name to `gounifi` to reuse
their JSON parsing and type inference logic.

## Files to Vendor (parsing infrastructure only)
- `resources.go` - Resource, FieldInfo structs, JSON parsing, type inference
- `customize.go` - Field customization system
- `validation.go` - Regex-based validation helpers

## Attribution Requirements
Each vendored file needs this header:
```go
// Code in this file is copied from github.com/filipowm/go-unifi/codegen
// Licensed under MPL-2.0 - https://github.com/filipowm/go-unifi/blob/main/LICENSE
//
// DO NOT EDIT MANUALLY - synced from upstream via \`task sync-gounifi\`
// Source version: see ../.go-unifi-version
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- `task sync-gounifi` successfully clones and patches go-unifi codegen
- `internal/gounifi/` contains patched files with proper attribution
- Integration test passes: can parse JSON specs using vendored code
- Renovate config includes custom manager for version file
close_reason: Vendored go-unifi codegen to internal/gounifi/, build passes, lint passes

title: Phase 3: MCP Templates & Generator
description:
**BEFORE STARTING:** Read the full implementation plan at:
/Users/coneill/.claude/plans/enchanted-imagining-breeze.md

## Steps
1. Create `tool.go.tmpl` - MCP tool implementation template
2. Create `tool_test.go.tmpl` - Generated test template
3. Create `manifest.json.tmpl` - Static manifest template
4. Create `registry.go.tmpl` - Tool registry template
5. Write thin generator (~50 lines): call vendored parsing ‚Üí render templates
6. Write unit tests for generator (90%+ coverage)

## Generator Architecture
The generator imports vendored parsing code:
```go
import "github.com/claytono/go-unifi-mcp/internal/gounifi"

func main() {
    resources, _ := gounifi.BuildResourcesFromDownloadedFields(
        ".tmp/go-unifi/codegen/fields",
        customizer,
        false,
    )
    for _, r := range resources {
        generateMCPTool(r)  // Our MCP template
    }
}
```

## CRUD Operations Inference
Uses go-unifi's `IsSetting()` method:
| Resource Type | Detection | Operations |
|--------------|-----------|------------|
| Settings | `r.IsSetting()` returns true | get, update |
| Device | `r.StructName == "Device"` | list, get |
| All others | Default | list, get, create, update, delete |

## Generated Output
- `internal/tools/*.gen.go` - Tool implementations
- `internal/tools/*_test.gen.go` - Generated tests
- `internal/manifest/manifest.gen.json` - Static manifest
- `internal/registry/registry.gen.go` - Tool registry

## Acceptance Criteria
- Templates render valid Go code
- Generator produces 80+ tool files from go-unifi specs
- Generated tests compile and pass
- Manifest JSON is valid and contains all tools
- Generator has 90%+ test coverage

title: Phase 5: Meta-Tools & Lazy Mode
description:
**BEFORE STARTING:** Read the full implementation plan at:
/Users/coneill/.claude/plans/enchanted-imagining-breeze.md

## Steps
1. Implement `unifi_tool_index` - read from generated manifest
2. Implement `unifi_execute` - dispatcher to actual tools
3. Implement `unifi_batch` - parallel execution
4. Implement lazy mode tool loading
5. Write integration tests (90%+ coverage)

## Context Optimization (Lazy/Eager Modes)

### Lazy Mode (Default) - ~200 tokens
Only 3 meta-tools registered initially:
1. **`unifi_tool_index`** - Returns full tool catalog from static manifest
2. **`unifi_execute`** - Executes a tool by name with arguments
3. **`unifi_batch`** - Executes multiple tools in parallel

### Eager Mode - ~5000 tokens
All 80+ tools registered directly. Useful for development/debugging.

## Project Structure
```
internal/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ meta/                  # Meta-tools (hand-written)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tool_index.go
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tool_index_test.go
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ execute.go
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ execute_test.go
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ batch.go
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ batch_test.go
```

## Integration Test
```go
func TestLazyModeE2E(t *testing.T) {
    server := NewServer(testConfig)
    st, ct := mcp.NewInMemoryTransports()
    _, _ = server.Connect(ctx, st, nil)
    client, _ := mcp.NewClient(...).Connect(ctx, ct, nil)

    // List tools - should only see meta-tools
    tools, _ := client.ListTools(ctx, nil)
    assert.Len(t, tools.Tools, 3)

    // Call tool_index
    result, _ := client.CallTool(ctx, &mcp.CallToolParams{
        Name: "unifi_tool_index",
    })
    // Assert 80+ tools in manifest

    // Execute a tool via unifi_execute
    result, _ = client.CallTool(ctx, &mcp.CallToolParams{
        Name: "unifi_execute",
        Arguments: map[string]any{
            "tool": "list_networks",
            "arguments": map[string]any{"site": "default"},
        },
    })
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- Lazy mode exposes exactly 3 meta-tools
- `unifi_tool_index` returns complete manifest with 80+ tools
- `unifi_execute` correctly dispatches to underlying tools
- `unifi_batch` executes multiple tools in parallel
- Mode switching works via UNIFI_TOOL_MODE env var
- Tests achieve 90%+ coverage
